q: What are some things you can do after being bitten by an animal or a person?
a: After being bitten, you should clean the skin around the wound with soap and warm water, try to remove any objects like teeth, hair, or dirt from the wound, gently squeeze the wound to make it bleed slightly, apply a dry dressing or clean cloth firmly to stop bleeding, pat the wound dry and cover it with a clean dressing, and take paracetamol or ibuprofen for pain and swelling.

q: When should you seek urgent advice from NHS 111 after a bite?
a: You should seek urgent advice from NHS 111 if there are still objects like teeth, hair, or dirt in the wound, the bite is hot or swollen, you have a high temperature, fluid is leaking from the bite, the bite smells unpleasant, you were bitten on your hands or feet, or you were bitten by a person.

q: What should you do if you've been bitten on your face or head and cannot stop the bleeding?
a: If you've been bitten on your face or head and cannot stop the bleeding, you should go to A&E immediately. Call 999 for an ambulance if you're unable to go to A&E. If a body part has been torn off, wrap it in clean tissue, put it in a plastic bag, surround with ice, and take it with you to the hospital.

q: What treatments may be given for animal and human bites?
a: For animal and human bites, a doctor or nurse may clean the bite thoroughly, close the wound with stitches, sticky strips, or special glue, or leave it open to heal. Antibiotics may be given to prevent infection, and there may be a risk assessment for tetanus and rabies. If bitten by a person, a blood test may also be offered for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV.

q: Why is it important to clean the skin around the wound after an animal or human bite?
a: It is important to clean the skin around the wound after an animal or human bite to reduce the risk of infection.

q: What should you do if the wound from an animal or human bite is bleeding heavily?
a: If the wound from an animal or human bite is bleeding heavily after cleaning, you should press a dry dressing or clean cloth firmly onto the wound to stop the bleeding.

q: What should you do if the bite from an animal or human smells unpleasant?
a: If the bite from an animal or human smells unpleasant, you should seek urgent advice from NHS 111.

q: Why might a doctor or nurse remove a part of the affected area while cleaning a bite wound?
a: A doctor or nurse might remove a part of the affected area while cleaning a bite wound if the wound is very dirty, in order to reduce the risk of infection.

q: What types of infections can be prevented through treatment after a bite from a person?
a: Treatment after a bite from a person can prevent tetanus, rabies, hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV infections.

q: Why should children under 16 not take aspirin for pain and swelling after a bite?
a: Children under 16 should not take aspirin for pain and swelling after a bite because of the risk of a rare but serious condition called Reye's syndrome.

q: What should I do after being bitten by an animal or a person?
a: After being bitten, you should clean the skin around the wound with soap and warm water, remove any objects like teeth, hair or dirt from the wound, gently squeeze the wound to make it bleed slightly (if it's not already bleeding), and apply a dry dressing or clean cloth to stop the bleeding. It's also recommended to take pain relievers like paracetamol or ibuprofen.

q: When should I seek medical help after an animal or human bite?
a: You should seek medical help if there are still objects in the wound, if the bite is hot or swollen, if you have a high temperature, if fluid is leaking from the bite, if the bite smells unpleasant, if you were bitten on your hands or feet, or if you were bitten by a person.

q: What should I do if the animal or human bite is severe?
a: If the bite is severe, you should go to the nearest A&E if the wound is large or deep, you were bitten on your face or head, or if you cannot stop the bleeding. If you're unable to go to A&E, call 999 for an ambulance. If a body part has been torn off, wrap it in clean tissue, put it in a plastic bag with some ice, and take it with you to the hospital.

q: What treatments are available for animal and human bites?
a: If you've been bitten, a doctor or nurse will check the wound and may clean it thoroughly, close it with stitches, strips or glue, or leave it open to heal. You may be given antibiotics to prevent infection and your risk of tetanus and rabies will be assessed. A blood test may also be offered if you've been bitten by a person to check for hepatitis B, hepatitis C, and HIV.

q: How should I clean a wound from an animal or human bite?
a: To clean the wound, you should use soap and warm water or antiseptic. Be careful not to get antiseptic in the wound. You can also remove any objects like teeth, hair, or dirt from the wound using running water.

q: Why should I gently squeeze the wound after an animal or human bite?
a: Gently squeezing the wound after an animal or human bite can help it bleed slightly, which can reduce the risk of infection.

q: What should I do to stop the bleeding after cleaning the wound?
a: After cleaning the wound, you should press a dry dressing or clean cloth firmly onto the wound to stop the bleeding. This will help promote clotting.

q: Are there any pain relievers I can take after an animal or human bite?
a: Yes, you can take pain relievers like paracetamol or ibuprofen to help ease any pain and swelling. However, children under 16 should not take aspirin.

q: When should I call NHS 111 for help after an animal or human bite?
a: You should call NHS 111 if you've been bitten and there are still objects in the wound, if the bite is hot or swollen, if you have a high temperature, if fluid is leaking from the bite, if the bite smells unpleasant, if you were bitten on your hands or feet, or if you were bitten by a person.

q: What should I do if a body part has been torn off from an animal or human bite?
a: If a body part has been torn off, you should wrap it in clean tissue, put it in a plastic bag with some ice, and take it with you to the hospital. It's important to seek immediate medical attention in this case.
